documents.title: thank you everyone : that 's it for jesse 's webchat today !
text: jesse has to head off now , so we are wrapping up .
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:31pm thanks to everyone for your questions - signing off thank you very much to everyone who submitted questions .
and thank you to jesse for answering questions and giving us his time .
fapaydin asks : can you tell us about how you prepare for an audition ?
( actually , do you do auditions at all ? )
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:26pm i do n't have very good advice except that the nervousness you probably feel is not a bad thing .
it will most likely help you and it 's not always a sign of something being wrong .
good luck !
snazzysnape wants to know : which film challenged you the most as an actor ?
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:24pm i always feel that whatever i 'm doing at any given moment is the hardest thing and also the thing i 'm mostly likely to fail at .

i have had the most challenging experiences in acting environments that probably appear to be relatively simple or straightforward and an easier time with movies like the double , which i imagine just technically , may seem much more difficult .
dano0o0 asks : i saw night moves a while ago , really enjoyed it and your performance and i was just wondering whether you prefer playing darker more morally ambiguous characters like that ?

guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:21pm it is always a fun challenge to play roles that are morally ambiguous because it is that much more difficult to find a way to justify their behavior/sympathize with them .
however , i imagine that these characters , if asked , would be able to justify their behavior and think of themselves as righteous even though they are hurting others .
in this way , all characters are probably similarly driven by their own version of right even if , to an audience or to the other characters in the story , it can seem evil or selfish or damaging .
harrison has a second question : thank you for answering my question !
what is it like being away from home/traveling for so long ?
how does it affect your choosing projects ?

guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:16pm i enjoy traveling and one of the perks of working in an isolated environment on a movie for a given period of time is being able to immerse yourself in the project .
i live in new york and when i do a play there , it is a bit distracting to maintain a normal life while being immersed in the play .

i did a movie earlier this year called the end of the tour which took place in the midwest region of the us and the film was very distinctly tied into that area and the other actor and i felt like we had a more authentic experience filming the movie where it took place and indulging in that different environment .

callum brown1 wants to know : what differences have you found between working on smaller , more independent films like the double and the social network , in comparison to the studio-fare of now you see me and batman v superman ?
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:11pm there is a strange irony to this .
i filmed now you see me , in which i play a magician , back to back with night moves , a smaller film about an environmental activist who suffers from unresolved rage .

during the filming of now you see me , because it took several months to film , i had the opportunity to try scenes several different ways and spend hours working on a particular moment of the movie .

conversely , in night moves , which is a film that you could argue focuses more on the nuances of character or the subtleties of a situation , i had one or two takes of each scene before moving on to the next scene .
so often , these bigger movies will allow the actors to experiment in a way that smaller movies , solely because of budget/scheduling , do n't permit .
faitsok asks : can you tell us a little bit more about american ultra ?

: ) guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:06pm we just finished filming this movie so it is a bit early to digest , but it was a wonderful experience playing this role , which is a guy who has no direction in life who discovers he was brainwashed to be a fighter in a government program based on the mk-ultra program in the states .
it turns from a very personal and intimate story of my character and his girlfriend , played by kristen stewart , into a stylized and kinetic movie about this guy being hunted .
tommyboy79 asks : give us aspiring directors something you learnt from working with david fincher .
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 12:02pm it is a bit difficult to describe his directing process because i was not watching him with any objectivity .
but we sat on a panel at a middle school together and he was asked this question and his answer was very interesting .
he said that modern technology makes it impossible to make any excuses for not making something .
because it is so cheap and easy to make a movie compared to what it would have taken even ten years ago , there should be no reason to not make something .

text: which one , which one the double star jesse eisenberg reads through your questions photograph : /ben beaumont-thomas , the guardian
harrison asks : have you thought about producing your own projects ?

guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 11:58am i write plays that are produced in new york and they take quite a while to come to fruition so i am usually in a state of producing , but for the theater .
i hope to do one of them here at some point .

my last play starred vanessa redgrave and i have seen her perform theater here many times and love the scene , which is different from new york because the government funds some wonderful productions here that rival our for-profit theaters in new york
mscaramello73 asks : just wanted to know what it was like for him working with kristen stewart for the 2nd time in american ultra ?
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 11:54am kristen and i have similar style of working and a similar sensibility i think .
she 's obviously a wonderful actress and is also very funny in both films we did , which are comedic in tone but unusually so .
ryan boyle asks : what influences you most when choosing your next film - director , script , cast , gut feeling ?
thanks .
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 11:51am ideally , i like to play a role that i can both add something to and find interesting over the course of a lengthy film shoot .
it is a bit difficult to play a character that is just one characteristic because it inevitably feels repetitive .
it is not always possible to play such multidimensional roles like in these two movies , the double and night moves , but when the opportunity arises , i feel lucky to join
michaelamichael asks : i thought you were marvellous in the double.how is richard ayoade as a director ?
have you seen darkplace ?
guardian contributor jesseisenberg 29 july 2014 11:49am richard is a very talented man with an unusual aesthetic .
he was able to make a movie that was emotionally realistic even though it is a comedy and takes place in a surreal and parallel universe .
it 's an unique combination that perfectly reflects his sensibilites .

text: from his awkward teen in rodger dodger , so wet behind the ears his shoulders were practically soaking , to the arrogant street magician of surprise hit now you see me , jesse eisenberg has become a go-to man in hollywood for characters where you 're never sure what they 're going to do next .
he trades in a meek , inquisitive face and a baffled or drily amused demeanour but can switch it all up for a devastating ruthlessness and steely resolve .
it 's those qualities on show in his most well-known part , playing mark zuckerberg in the social network .
they also feature in his new film night moves , where he plays an eco-terrorist plotting to blow up a dam , in a low-budget , high-tensile thriller from kelly reichart .

they 'll be the heart of one of the most anticipated films of the decade , batman v superman : dawn of justice , in which he plays megavillain lex luthor , and he shows off both sides of his personality playing two doppelgangers in the double , which is released on dvd on 4 august .
to find out more , check out eisenberg 's interview with the guardian 's alex godfrey , discussing why he never reads his press , being in the public eye and the alienation of new york city .
eisenberg joins us at 11.30am bst on tuesday 29 july to answer your questions about these and his other films , and indeed anything else about his impressive and aty career .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
